thats what I do, DarkBASIC is fun and easy to me
here are some basic types of data from the book:

*INTEGER NUMBERS
An integer number can hold a whole number, but no fraction.for the value to be negative, you must not use commas as part of the the number as this would genarate a SYNTAX Error. examples of integer numbers:

42
10000
-233000
-100

*REAL NUMBERS
A real number can hold a whole number or a fractional number that uses a decimal point.For the value to be negative, you must place a hyphen symbol (-) before the value. Examples of real numbers:

20.0005
99.9
-5000.12
-9999.9991

I think usually falling works something like this:

You fall, the programme checks if you're in the ground.
Nope!

You fall, the programme checks if you're in the ground.
Nope!

You fall, the programme checks if you're in the ground.
Yes, you can't really be here, and the programme moves you up again a little bit.Retodon8

title: Re: he he!
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]You fall, the programme checks if you're in the ground.
Nope!

You fall, the programme checks if you're in the ground.
Yes, you can't really be here, and the programme moves you up again a little bit.[hr][/quote]
This is not how I would do it. Why go through the calculation of falling and THEN check, wouldn't you put the check first. If you are on the ground it would make you fall, do the check, and then UNDO what was just done. And wouldn't that just make the player bob up and down? I mean you are checking anyway so by putting the check first it should just make your program faster.

for example:

Check
Not on ground
Fall

Check
On ground
